lesson_typing.typing_justification: The lesson repeatedly contrasts series and parallel circuits and focuses on clarifying the difference between them, which aligns more closely with a Comparative Concept lesson than a pure Foundational Concept introduction.

arcs.label: Arc A – Foundational concept
arcs.description: Introduces the basic idea of an electric circuit and current flow, with a first simple model of components connected in a loop.

arcs.label: Arc B – Comparative concept
arcs.description: Compares series and parallel circuits, highlighting differences in voltage, current distribution and what happens when one component fails.

template_fit.reason: The lesson mixes a Foundational Concept arc (what a circuit is) with a Comparative Concept arc (series vs parallel), so the cognitive intent is split between introducing a new idea and differentiating related ideas.

template_structure_compliance.reason: There is a recognisable overview and some concept development, but relationships and application are interleaved, and a short guided problem set appears where a Conceptual Relationships block should be.

cognitive_integrity.reason: Two distinct conceptual arcs are developed to similar depth: one builds a first model of a simple circuit, and another contrasts series and parallel circuits with their own examples and explanations.

template_boundary_discipline.reason: Alongside conceptual explanation, the lesson includes several step-by-step worked examples calculating current and voltage, plus a small practice set, which encroaches on Skills and Task territory.

progressive_model_principle.reason: The core model of a simple circuit is mostly clear, but it is quickly followed by multiple variations and edge cases (different configurations, short circuits), which slightly dilute the first, clean model.

lesson_economy_and_cognitive_load.reason: The lesson attempts to introduce basic circuits, compare series vs parallel, and run through six quantitative examples in a single sitting, which is beyond a single natural unit of conceptual integrity.

priority_index.priority_explanation: The mixed intent, dual conceptual arcs, and skills drift warrant a moderate restructuring priority; the overload factor is elevated due to the number of concepts and examples packed into one lesson.
